I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2006, the Government of India asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help it 
develop the infrastructure the country needs to tap the large economic potential of its tourism 
sector. As a first step, ADB provided technical assistance (TA) in 2006 to create a national 
tourism infrastructure development road map.1 The TA assessed tourism market trends and the 
endowments, destinations, and circuits in the country with the highest tourism potential. It also 
identified the infrastructure requirements for these circuits over the next 10 years and the 
institutional and regulatory constraints to sustainable tourism growth. ADB provided additional 
two-phase  TA  in  2007  after  the  government  sought  its  assistance  in  preparing  a  tourism 
infrastructure  development  project  for  possible  ADB  financing.2 Phase  1  prepared  a  more 
specific  road  map  for  each  of  four  participating  states—Himachal  Pradesh,  Punjab,  and 
Uttarakhand, the three main states of an identified northwest Himalayan heritage tourism circuit; 
and Tamil Nadu, the anchor state of the south heritage tourism circuit. A framework was also 
prepared  for  policy  and  sector  reforms  necessary  to  develop  environmentally  sustainable, 
culturally sensitive, and socially inclusive tourism.3 Phase 2 of this TA sought to improve the 
project management and implementation capacities of the relevant agencies and ready them for 
project implementation. Based on the phase 1 outputs, an ADB fact-finding mission carried out 
due diligence in February–March 2010 and the ensuing tourism infrastructure development 
investment  project  was  approved  in  September  2010,  providing  the  four  states  with  a 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to develop the tourism sector.4 The government has now 
requested  this  capacity  development  TA  to  supplement  phase  2  of  the  second  TA.5 This 
capacity development TA will also strengthen the pro-poor design of the MFF. The preliminary 
design and monitoring framework, which reflects the impact, outcome, and outputs agreed on 
by the government and ADB, is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  India is one of the fast-growing economies in the world. Its gross domestic product (GDP) 
expanded  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  7.7%  during  FY2002–FY2007  and  is  forecast  to 
increase to 8.7% during the 11th Five-Year Plan (2007–2012). India has had mixed success in 
its efforts to make this economic growth more inclusive. The percentage of the population below 
the poverty line decreased from 36% in FY1994 to 27.5% in FY2005 but the rate of decline did 
not  match  GDP  growth.  A  rural–urban  divide  is  rapidly  widening.  Per  capita  household 
expenditure in rural areas is estimated at less than half of that in urban areas and economic 
growth  has  not  been  uniform  across  India’s  regions.  Reducing  rural–urban  disparities  by 
generating growth in the agriculture sector alone is neither easy nor effective. To narrow the gap, 
it is important that the non-agriculture and service sectors in rural areas also be stimulated to 
provide more economic opportunities and employment.

3.  India has the potential to become one of the world’s top tourist destinations. The sector 
has grown quickly, with total foreign tourist arrivals increasing from 2.38 million in 2002 to 
around 5.37 million in 2008, a 126% rise overall and an average growth of 14.6% a year. 
Tourism generated about $11.75 billion in foreign exchange in 2008. Domestic tourism is also 
growing. Total visits rose from 269.6 million in 2002 to 562.9 million in 2008 (up about 109% 
overall or 13.1% on average per annum).6 India’s prospects are good in virtually every tourism 
field—cultural, religious, ecological, adventure, medical, and relaxation. Richly varied tourist 
attractions permit product differentiation and branding. Rapid expansion and upgrading of the 
sector’s infrastructure and services to international standards will increase India’s appeal and 
make it more efficient and better able to compete with other international destinations.7 More 
jobs and improved livelihoods will result.  
 
4.  In 2002, new government policy recognized tourism’s strong potential for growth and 
employment  generation,  particularly  in  less-developed  parts  of  the  country.  In  2003–2004, 
according to surveys, the tourism sector contributed only 5.9% to the GDP, much lower, for 
example, than the world average of 10.4% in 2007.8 At the time, it was providing about 41.8 
million people with full-time jobs. With increased investment, the sector has a great deal of room 
to grow, to generate more direct and indirect employment through its forward and backward 
linkages,  and  to  make  a  beneficial  impact  on  rural  poverty  and  rural–urban  inequity.  The 
government’s tourism strategy is reflected in its current Five-Year Plan and in ADB’s India 
country partnership strategy 2009–2012, which supports development of urban infrastructure 
needed to strengthen the tourism potential of heritage cities in an environmentally sustainable 
manner.9 
 
5.  To  this  end,  the  government  has  committed  to  (i) assisting  the  states  with  tourism 
development; (ii) encouraging private sector provision of tourist facilities and services through 
public  sector  infrastructure  development;  and  (iii) providing  regulatory  support  to  ensure 
sustainable tourism. The tourism sector road map for the country prepared with ADB’s TA sets 
targets for increases in visitor volumes, average length of stay, and spending (footnote 1). It 
also emphasizes more equitable sharing of tourism benefits with local communities. The road 
map includes a set of recommendations for capacity building and human resource development. 
While the sector’s growth during the 10th Five-Year Plan period (2002–2007) was impressive, 
targets under the current plan, including 10 million international tourist arrivals by 2011 as well 
as  812  million  domestic  tourist  visits,  have  proved  challenging,  due  in  part  to  the  global 
economic slowdown that started in 2008. 
 
6.  Private sector participation is a relatively recent phenomenon in India’s tourism sector. 
As more private enterprises join the industry, many states are still making the transition from 
being tourism service providers to promoting and regulating tourism. If tourism’s full economic 
potential is to be unleashed, however, the public sector has a key role to play by developing the 
necessary infrastructure. It must address the lack and poor quality of connectivity infrastructure 
to the states from India’s gateways and between the tourist attractions within each state. The 
destinations themselves lack such basic services as water supply, sanitation, and solid waste 
management. Infrastructure to support community-based tourism is almost nonexistent.

7.  While such infrastructure is put in place under the MFF, the tourism sector must be 
reformed so that it can develop more sustainably and be more inclusive. Key challenges include 
(i) insufficient public sector financing for balanced distribution of economic opportunities across 
each state; (ii) inadequate institutional capacities for heritage site management; (iii) the absence 
of an effective enabling environment for greater private sector participation and, in particular, of 
policy and regulatory reforms to provide for adaptive reuse of publicly-owned heritage buildings 
so that additional means of cost recovery are established; (iv) poor operation and maintenance 
of tourism infrastructure; and (v) the lack of effective mechanisms to engage local communities 
in the tourism value chain through community-based, tourism-related economic and livelihood 
activities.  Detailed  discussions  about  the  national  tourism  development  road  map  and  the 
tourism road maps of the four participating states can be found in the framework financing 
agreement for the MFF (footnote 4). In particular, the participating states will promote homestay 
programs and other noncommercial or semicommercial lodging alternatives such as bed and 
breakfast (B&B) facilities. 
 
8.   During the crucial MFF start-up period, before this task is handed over to the loan-
funded  consultant  teams,  the  capacity  development  TA  will  help  the  participating  states 
overcome these key challenges and successfully jump-start the policy-driven sector reforms.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA impact will be the successful implementation of the MFF, particularly during its 
start-up  period.  The  impact  can  be  assessed  by  the  project  readiness  checklist  of  the 
Department of Economic Affairs for each participating state. The expected outcome will be 
increased  readiness  to  implement  the  MFF  when  the  TA  ends  at  the  executing  agency, 
implementing agencies, and relevant local communities of each participating state. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Two state-based consultant teams will be engaged to assist two of the client states (i.e., 
team 1 in Tamil Nadu and team 2 in Uttarakhand). Individuals already recruited under phase 2 
of the previous ADB TA will make up the respective state-based consultant teams for Himachal 
Pradesh and Punjab. Another recruit from that TA will act as a safeguards specialist (social and 
environment) for Himachal Pradesh and Punjab (footnote 2). The third consultant team (team 3) 
under this TA will provide specialized support for all four participating states, each of which is 
supported by a state-based consultant team (i.e., team 1 for Tamil Nadu and team 2 for 
Uttarakhand under this TA, and one team each for Himachal Pradesh and Punjab under phase 
2 of the previous ADB TA). 
 
11.  The expected TA outputs include (i) overall project management capacity improvement 
at the executing agencies and implementing agencies of the participating states, with respect to 
preparation  of  various  subprojects  (project  readiness  on  general  management);  (ii) overall 
procurement management capacity improvement at the executing agencies and implementing 
agencies,  with  respect  to  preparation  of  tendering  for  subprojects  (project  readiness  on 
procurement); (iii) preparation and pilot implementation of a strategy to facilitate partnerships 
with the private sector and to promote community participation in tourism-related economic 
activities, such as B&Bs, homestay programs, and traditional culture and crafts, particularly in 
the rural areas concerned; (iv) preparation of tourist destination management and master plans,

4   
including  mobility  plans,  with  sections  on  gender  aspects,  along  with  support  for  their 
endorsement; and (v) a baseline survey of gender-disaggregated employment statistics, which 
will be used for target setting in some of the design and monitoring framework indicators. 
Promotion  of  ecotourism  is  a  key  feature  of  the  MFF.  Promotion  of  B&Bs  and  homestay 
programs should help generate significant alternative livelihood opportunities in rural areas, 
especially for women. Best practices in managing these facilities will be shared to help ensure a 
successful roll-out of rural livelihood enhancement programs. 
 
12.  To put the strategy of promoting community participation in tourism-related economic 
activities  into  effect,  workshops  and  seminars  will  be  conducted  not  only  for  relevant 
government  staff  members  but  also  for  local  communities,  concerned  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations, and civil society groups. Each of the 
three consultant teams under this TA will engage an NGO as a subcontractor for training the 
diverse group of people mentioned above. The NGOs’ specific tasks will include (i) developing 
awareness about tourism; (ii) training for undertaking community-based tourism (CBT) business 
operations and activities; (iii) training for producing and marketing products in the tourism value 
chain, such as handicrafts, B&Bs, homestay programs, and other noncommercial or semi-
commercial lodging alternatives; and (iv) training to minimize the negative social impacts of 
tourism and to help generate more employment through the MFF. The subcontractor NGOs for 
team 1 for Tamil Nadu and team 2 for Uttarakhand will look after their respective states while 
the subcontractor for team 3 will look after the two participating states of Himachal Pradesh and 
Punjab. 
 
13.  Assumptions and risks.  One risk faced by the MFF that the TA is designed to support 
is deterioration in global and/or domestic economic conditions that might reduce market demand 
for tourism. Another risk involves the potential for poor implementation performance and/or 
implementation delays. While the first is beyond its control, the TA will significantly mitigate the 
second and help ensure the realization of expected benefits and impacts. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The estimated cost of the TA will be the equivalent of $1,200,000. The government has 
requested that ADB finance the equivalent of $1,000,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
Government of India will finance the balance of the cost, equivalent to $200,000, through the 
provision of office space, remuneration for counterpart staff (including their field per diem and 
transportation), and other in-kind contributions (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  executing  agencies  will  be  the  departments  of  tourism  or  the  equivalent 
departments of the four participating states. The implementing agencies will be the states’ 
tourism boards or the equivalent. At the state level, based on the overall strategic guidance 
provided by the executing agency, each state-based consultant team (teams 1 and 2 under this 
TA, and two teams each of which consists of individual consultants recruited under phase 2 of 
the  previous  ADB  TA)  will  support  the  staffs  of  the  executing  agency,  the  implementing 
agencies, and other agencies concerned to improve project management and implementation 
capacities and advance project preparedness. The specialized consultant team (team 3) will 
provide support on various subject areas, based on the needs of each of the four states.

5
16.  The  participating  states  will  provide  (i) all  relevant  documents,  data,  statistics, 
information, and maps at their disposal; (ii) appropriate and qualified counterpart staff, as well 
as their field per diem and field transport costs; (iii) a program director from each executing 
agency to be assigned before the consultant mobilization; (iv) office accommodation and office 
equipment, including desks and chairs, and local communication; (v) logistical assistance for 
workshops and seminars, including the venues, and identification and recruitment of participants; 
and (vi) utility costs, covering electricity and water. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months with a target start-up of January 2011. Each 
state-based consultant team (team 1 for Tamil Nadu and team 2 for Uttarakhand) consists of 
(i) a procurement specialist; (ii) a civil engineer; and (iii) a conservation architect and/or planner 
(all national). The specialist consultant team (team 3) consists of (i) a safeguards specialist 
(social and environment, national); (ii) a financial management specialist (national); and (iii) a 
planner (international). Either the procurement specialist or the civil engineer will play the role of 
team leader for teams 1 and 2. Each of the three teams will engage an NGO in the preparation 
and pilot implementation of the strategy to promote community participation in tourism-related 
economic activities. The planner will lead team 3 and also carry out overall coordination among 
the four participating states, their respective state-based consultant teams, one individually-
recruited  safeguards  specialist  (social  and  environment),  and  ADB.  The  outline  terms  of 
reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). About 88 person-months of consulting 
services  will  be  required—8  person-months  from  international  consultants  and  80  person-
months from national consultants. Each of the three consultant teams will be recruited on a 
corporate basis under the quality- and cost-based selection method using biodata technical 
proposal. The default quality-cost ratio of 80:20 will be used for all the three contract packages. 
To avoid potential conflict of interest between the assignments under this TA and the ensuing 
loan-funded state-based assignments, the firm awarded the team 3 assignment will not be 
allowed to bid for any of the loan-funded state-based assignments, while the firms awarded the 
team  1  and  team  2  assignments  will  not  be  permitted  to  bid  for  any  of  the  loan-funded 
assignments in the state each serves under the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made 
in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
for Capacity Development for Project Management of Infrastructure Development for Rural 
Livelihood Enhancement, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
1.  The  collective  tasks  of  each  of  the  implementation  capacity  development  support 
consultant teams will include, amongst other tasks, the following: 
 
1.  State-Based Teams (Team 1 for Tamil Nadu and Team 2 for Uttarakhand) 
 
2.  Project management. Each team will (i) assess the capacity of the executing agency 
and implementing agencies to manage the activities under the loan-funded project and identify 
the need for capacity building for timely and effective implementation of the project and the 
policy reform actions linked to the project (by using, in particular, the project readiness checklist 
of the Department of Economic Affairs; (ii) recommend an optimal managerial and technical 
personnel  structure,  together  with  related  job  descriptions  for  key  personnel;  (iii) assist  in 
establishing the project management unit (PMU) and project implementation units (PIUs) for the 
project; (iv) develop and conduct training programs for key personnel to familiarize them with 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) procedures and develop their capacity to undertake project 
management activities effectively; (v) assist in developing project management systems and 
procedures; (vi) assist in establishing the systems for loan implementation, as applicable (e.g., 
subproject preparation and appraisal); (vii) provide hands-on assistance for the PMU and PIUs 
in their preparation and finalization of all documentation for recruitment of consultants for project 
management, and advance contracting; and (viii) provide hands-on assistance for the PMU in 
all other project management-related activities. 
 
3.  Procurement. The team will (i) assist the PIUs in procurement activities; (ii) assist the 
PMU in performing possible advance procurement actions for consultancy and goods and civil 
works contracts, in accordance with ADB guidelines and procedures, to expedite the award of 
contracts; (iii) review the draft tender documents already prepared under the proposed loan-
funded project and finalize their contract packaging and mode of procurement; (iv) provide on-
the-job training on procurement; and (v) assist the PMU in identifying the fast-track contract 
packages that can be undertaken early in the project implementation. 
 
4.  Institutional  development.  The  team  will  identify  the  preparatory  activities  for 
implementing the policy reform actions and assist the states in taking such actions on priority 
aspects, in cooperation with the specialized consultant team. The team will assess immediate 
needs for capacity building based on the proposals made during phase 1 of the technical 
assistance (TA) for Preparing the Inclusive Tourism Infrastructure Development Project1 and 
begin implementing priority capacity-building activities. The priority institutional development 
activities will focus on enhancing capacities for sustainable management of the assets to be 
created under the project. 
 
2.  Specialized Team (Team 3) 
 
5.  In cooperation with each of the state-based consultant teams, the team will carry out 
(i) preparation and pilot implementation of overall strategy to promote community participation in 
tourism-related economic activities, such as bed and breakfasts (B&Bs), and traditional culture 
and  crafts,  in  cooperation  with  the  three  subcontractor  NGOs;  (ii) preparation  of  tourist 
destination  management  and  master  plans,  including  comprehensive  mobility  plans,  with

compliance review and monitoring (for Tamil Nadu and Uttarakhand only);2 and (v) assistance

3.  Subcontractor Nongovernment Organizations for the Three Teams 
 
6.  Each of the three teams will engage the services of an NGO in the preparation and pilot 
implementation of a strategy to promote community participation in tourism-related economic 
activities. The NGO must act as a subcontractor to its team to carry out several specific tasks, 
including: (i) developing awareness about tourism; (ii) training for undertaking community-based 
tourism  (CBT)  business  operations  and  activities;  (iii) training  for  producing  and  marketing 
products,  such  as  handicrafts,  homestay  programs,  B&Bs,  and  other  noncommercial  or 
semicommercial lodging alternatives, in the tourism value chain; and (iv) training to minimize the 
negative  social  impacts  of  tourism  and  to  help  generate  more  employment  through  the 
investment program. The funding allocation for this subcontracting is about US$10,000 for each 
team to carry out, inter alia, training for at least 40 individuals in at least two communities in 
each participating state on heritage management and tourism-related skills (with a target of 30% 
participation by women). The subcontractor NGOs for team 1 for Tamil Nadu and team 2 for 
Uttarakhand will look after their respective states while that for Team 3 will look after the two 
participating states of Himachal Pradesh and Punjab. 
 
B.  Individual Terms of Reference for Consultants 
 
1.  Procurement Specialist (national; 12 person-months each for teams 1 and 2) 
 
7.  A  graduate  civil  engineer  with  about  10  years  of  experience  in  procurement  of 
consultants, goods, civil works, and other services under externally-funded projects, preferably 
ADB.  He  or  she  should  have  expertise  in  the  current  procurement  procedures  of  ADB. 
Specifically, the procurement specialist will be required to: 
(i)  take overall responsibility for planning, coordinating, and executing all activities 
related  to  procurement  of  consultants,  goods,  and  civil  works,  in  close 
coordination with the PMU and other relevant government agencies; 
(ii)  assist the PMU in establishing a procurement management system based on 
ADB  guidelines,  including  consultant  recruitment  procedures  and  bidding 
procedures for goods and civil works, and covering prequalification of contractors, 
wherever necessary; 
(iii)  assist the PMU in recruiting loan-funded consultants for the project, i.e., a project 
management consultant and a design and supervision consultant; 
(iv)  prepare all necessary documents for recruitment of consultants, including the 
expression  of  interest,  the  terms  of  reference  for  the  project  management 
consultant  and  the  design  and  supervision  consultant,  and  the  request  for 
proposal for various subprojects; 
(v)  assist the PMU in evaluation of expressions of interest, technical and financial 
evaluations  of  proposals,  negotiations,  contract  award,  etc.  for  loan-funded 
consultants; 
                                                 
2  A safeguards specialist (social and environment) was already recruited individually under phase 2 of Technical 
Assistance for Preparing the Inclusive Tourism Infrastructure Development Project. Manila (TA 7014-IND) to look 
after Himachal Pradesh and Punjab on these aspects (main text footnote 2). This CDTA is supporting this previous 
ADB TA.

Appendix 3  11 
(vi)  review the suggested contract packaging for goods and civil works under the 
loan-funded project, finalize the packaging and mode of procurement, prepare 
procurement plan as per ADB procedures, and prioritize the contract packages 
based on the priorities of the PMU; 
(vii)  prepare all necessary documents for procurement of goods and civil works for 
the  loan-funded  project,  including  standard  bidding  documents,  technical 
specifications, special conditions of contract, bills of quantity based on survey 
results, etc.; and 
(viii)  assess the capacity of the executing agency and PMU staff to identify their 
capacity development needs vis-à-vis their responsibility in effectively managing 
procurement activities, and develop, coordinate, and provide training programs 
for key staff. 
 
2.  Civil Engineer (national; 12 person-months each for teams 1 and 2) 
 
8.  A  graduate  civil  engineer  with  about  10  years  of  experience  in  designing  basic 
infrastructure and services such as water supply, sanitation, solid waste management, roads, 
simple buildings, etc. Experience in ADB projects is desirable. Specifically, the civil engineer will 
be required to: 
(i)  identify requirements, prepare terms of reference, recruit competent agencies to 
conduct necessary surveys, studies, and investigations required for design of 
identified subprojects; 
(ii)  review  the  basic  design  criteria  and  oversee  the  preparation  of  technical 
specifications, engineering designs, cost estimates, bills of quantity, construction 
drawings, and implementation schedules for identified subprojects; 
(iii)  develop a construction management system and quality assurance and quality 
control system to ensure that selected contractors carry out the works as per the 
specifications and quality standards; and 
(iv)  assist  the  PMU  in  carrying  out  value  engineering  to  generate  a  number  of 
technically feasible designs, if required for the subproject, and work out the least 
cost alternative in order to ensure the best techno-economic designs. 
 
3.  Conservation Architect/Planner (national; 5 person-months each for teams 1 
and 2) 
 
9.  A graduate with degree in architecture with specialization in conservation and/or urban 
design and/or urban planning with about 10 years of experience in projects, which demonstrates 
expertise in the areas of conservation, renovation, and management of historic heritage sites, 
including monuments, buildings, and landscapes, and related development of visitor amenities, 
signage, and street furniture, parking, and access roads. Specifically, the conservation architect 
will be required to: 
(i)  review the designs suggested by master plans, management plans, and sample 
designs  prepared  by  phase  1  of  the  project  preparatory  TA  consultants  for 
sample  cluster  destination  subprojects  and  prioritize  the  subprojects  for 
execution; 
(ii)  identify  requirements,  prepare  terms  of  reference,  and  recruit  competent 
agencies  to  conduct  surveys,  studies,  and  investigations  required  for  the 
identified subprojects related to protection and/or conservation of the heritage 
sites; 
(iii)  assess, and when necessary, mitigate the impact of the subproject’s physical 
and nonphysical interventions on the affected heritage sites and/or monuments 
and their surrounding buffer zones;

12  Appendix 3 
 
(iv)  identify various requirements related to any interventions—conservation activities, 
restoration,  removals,  additions,  rearrangements,  alterations—that  affect  the 
physical structure and layout of the heritage sites, with particular attention to 
preserving the authenticity and integrity of such sites and structures; 
(v)  oversee  preparation  of  engineering  designs,  construction  drawings,  bills  of 
quantity,  cost  estimates,  and  bidding  documents  for  such  interventions  in 
consultation with the civil engineer and the procurement specialist; and 
(vi)  draft an operational manual for implementation of such a system. 
 
4.  Safeguards Specialist (Social and Environment) (national; 6 person-months 
for Team 3) 
 
10.  A graduate with degree in sociology, anthropology, environmental science or some other 
relevant discipline with about 10 years of experience, of which a substantial part should be in 
social and/or environmental safeguarding for externally-funded projects, preferably working with 
ADB.  He  or  she  should  have  expertise  in  social  and/or  environmental  management  of 
externally-funded  projects.  He  or  she  will  assist  the  executing  agencies  and  implementing 
agencies  in  the  safeguards  due  diligence  exercise  from  the  social  and  environmental 
safeguards perspective to ensure compliance with all relevant ADB policies. Specifically, the 
safeguards specialist (social and environment) will be required to: 
(i)  carry  out  adequate  investigations  (e.g.,  field  visits  to  project  locations  as 
appropriate)  and  consultations  with  affected  people  with  respect  to  all  the 
proposed  subprojects,  and  identify  the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement 
requirements of the project; 
(ii)  conduct  the  necessary  resettlement  plan  preparatory  surveys  of  impact 
assessment  by  type  of  physical  structure  (residential  buildings,  commercial 
buildings, etc.) and by type of impact on livelihood (temporary or permanent loss 
of business, etc.), an affected people census (including non-titleholding affected 
people  such  as  encroachers,  squatters,  vendors,  hawkers,  etc.),  and  a 
socioeconomic survey and studies;  
(iii)  prepare a resettlement plan for the project covering all the proposed subprojects 
in  accordance  with  relevant  government  policies  and  guidelines  and  ADB’s 
policies; 
(iv)  assess  the  implementation  and  monitoring  capacity  and  commitment  of  the 
executing agencies and the implementing agencies to undertake the measures 
prepared for the project in accordance with ADB’s involuntary resettlement and 
indigenous peoples safeguard requirements; and 
(v)  ensure timely and balanced safeguard categorizations of the project through 
discussions with the ADB project team and complete the involuntary resettlement 
checklist  and  categorization  form  and  the  indigenous  peoples  impact 
categorization form for the project for endorsement by ADB. 
 
5.  Financial Management Specialist (two nationals; 8 person-months each for 
Team3) 
 
11.  The financial management specialist should be a finance professional who is a certified 
public accountant or has earned a master of business administration degree in finance or has 
the equivalent of these qualifications, as well as about 15 years of experience, of which a 
substantial part should be in financial management for externally-funded projects, preferably 
working  with  ADB.  He  or  she  should  have  expertise  in  design,  implementation,  and 
management of ADB-financed projects. Specifically, the financial management specialist will be 
required to:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  design an appropriate project financial management system for the loan-funded 
project based on ADB’s guidelines and procedures and assist the executing 
agencies and the PMUs in implementing this system, which will include funds 
flow  monitoring,  claims  and  disbursements,  imprest  account  procedures, 
accounting and  reporting,  budgeting  and  control,  and  auditing  of  the  project 
accounts; 
(ii)  develop  a  financial  management  manual  for  the  loan-funded  project  and 
operationalize such a manual in the PMU and the PIUs; 
(iii)  compute the financial internal rate of return, the economic internal rate of return, 
and other indicators to assess the financial and economic viability of various 
alternatives of each identified subproject; 
(iv)  review government policies and procedures affecting the financial performance of 
the loan-funded project and identify critical areas for improvement; 
(v)  develop revenue enhancement measures and other innovative approaches for 
sustainable operation and maintenance of the cultural heritage sites; and 
(vi)  conduct training for the executing agencies and PMU personnel in financial and 
accounting systems and ADB procedures for disbursements and preparation of 
claims, maintenance of project accounts, audit of project accounts, and reporting. 
 
6.  Planner (international; 8 person-months) 
 
12.  The  planner  should  have  a  degree  in  urban  planning,  urban  design,  architecture, 
business administration, public administration, or another relevant discipline with about 15 years 
of experience in projects that demonstrates expertise in master planning in land use control and 
real estate development, urban transport, urban infrastructure and services, preferably including 
planning and/or management of major events such as conventions and festivals.  The planner 
will be responsible for several specific tasks: 
(i)  He  or  she  will  carry  out  event  planning  and  management  exercises,  in 
cooperation with relevant state-based consultant teams, for subproject tourist 
attractions that attract large number of visitors on peak days (e.g., auspicious 
days for pilgrimage). For example, the Naina Devi temple in Himachal Pradesh, 
which is a subproject sites, reportedly draws 200,000 visitors on the busiest day 
of the year. Most people come on buses and then on foot. For cases like this, he 
or she will properly plan bus terminal, footpaths, tents and/or temporary shelters, 
large number of temporary toilets, paramedic for orderly handling of the visitors; 
(ii)  He or she will carry out mobility planning exercises in cooperation with relevant 
state-based  consultant  teams.  These  should  result  in  a  miniversion  of  a 
comprehensive mobility plan advocated by the Ministry of Urban Development for 
relevant subproject site and focus on public transport. The planner will coordinate 
with those government officials and consultants working on the overall mobility 
plan; and 
(iii)  He or she will carry out a master planning exercise in cooperation with relevant 
state-based consultant teams for potential new tourist destinations that would, 
among  other  things,  facilitate  orderly  commercial  tourism  development.  The 
primary focus will be those candidate subproject areas where master plans (e.g., 
zoning, land use planning, building code, advertisement control, site and visitor 
management, safety standards, water supply, sewage and waste management 
plans and respective regulations for plot-owners and/or customers) do not exist 
yet. Significant potential for this exercise exists at some subproject sites, such as 
Pong Dam Lake subproject in Himachal Pradesh.
